passages.text: Aug 28: SFR/FR politics, on deregulation, FR price cut, Sky CH...

French Telcos - Update on SFR's debt restructuring and this week's political developments (note out yesterday) BT - Openreach MD advocates for softer Ofcom regulation in competitive areas Bouygues - Reduces price of 'Bbox Rentree' entry- level triple- play package Swiss Telcos - Sky launches fibre broadband, mobile services on Salt network DT - TMUS unveils 'SuperMobile' business plans DT - Installs over 240k fibre- optic connections in Germany in July German Telcos - Govt calls for input on national data centre strategy Satellites - Telesat names new CFO from October
Sunrise US roadshow - New York (8 Sept) and Boston (9 Sept) UK Leaders Conference (Vodafone and BT to attend) - London (18- 19 Nov) Please reach out for more details.
Recent research (here) Selected dates (here)

3 Sep - Deadline for EC public consultation on review of EU merger guidelines 16- 17 Sep - Application deadline for 26GHz and 40GHz band auctions in UK Q3 - Expected announcement of Cellnex data centre and Swiss sales Q3 - OTE closing Telekom Romania deal Oct - SFR to close debt restructuring program Oct - UK 26GHz and 40GHz band spectrum auctions (regulator expectation) Oct - Expected close of MasOrange FiberCo deal 5 Nov - KPN strategy update 11 Nov - TelenorCMD 19 Nov - NokiaCMD Nov - Sweden 1800MHz spectrum auction begins Nov - Telefónica to present new strategic plan Dec - EEC review the European Electronic Communications Code (EECC) 10 Dec - EC to publish Digital Networks Act H2 Telecom Italia Enterprise Day H2 - TEF/VOD ES to potentially announce stake sale in Fiberpass JV H2 - Germany's final decision on Vodafone/Vantage anti- competitive hindrance to 1&1 2025 - Norwegian 1500MHz and 26GHz spectrum auction (TBC, consultation ongoing)
Sources: Company reports, Bloomberg Finance L.P., Reuters See full calendar below

With this short note, we review recent developments in relation to SFR's ongoing debt restructuring plans, as well as emerging debates around how French PM Bayrou's surprise 8th September confidence vote might potentially impact the French Telcos. Highlights include: (1) On 4th August, the Paris Commercial Court approved SFR's accelerated safeguard, enabling implementation of its debt restructuring plans. According to La Tribune, unions have since filed an appeal, and SFR's Economic and Social Committee is concurrently attempting to suspend the safeguard. But reports indicate the public prosecutor's office has, by contrast, chosen not to appeal, leaving a successful suspension unlikely. Overall, we consider SFR's October debt restructuring plans to be on track. The closing of this restructuring process is seen as a pre- requisite to the potential consummation of French Telco consolidation talks; (2) Whilst this week's French political turmoil has seen both Bouygues and Orange's shares trade off \(\sim 5\%\) , we consider this a buying opportunity. Our economist expects the September confidence vote simply to pull forward the fall of the Bayrou government by a few months, resulting in yet another weak government. He considers a new lower- house election very unlikely. Critically, we argue that political change should not in any way impact French Telco consolidation prospects, and the compelling valuations of both Orange and Bouygues already over- discount generic macro risks. Ways in which political turmoil might impact the Telco sector include: (i) driving an extension of the current tax surcharge, (ii) helping buyers negotiate down the break- up value of SFR, and (iii) leading the government to place a portion of its stake in Orange. We consider any such effects modest and dwarfed by the rich catalyst pipelines offered by both Orange (OW, AFL) and Bouygues (upgraded to OW on Tuesday).

Mark Shurmer, Managing Director of Regulation at Openreach (BT), has urged Ofcom to ease market regulations in UK areas deemed competitive due to the presence of Virgin Media's fixed broadband network or three or more full fibre (FTTP) network providers. Openreach, holding 'Significant Market Power (SMP)', faces various rules to address competition concerns, including price controls and fair access requirements. Openreach's FTTP network covers nearly 20m premises, with plans to reach 30m by 2030. Ofcom's Telecoms Access Review 2026 aims to promote competition and investment in gigabit broadband, proposing to redefine competitive areas. Shurmer argues for reduced restrictions in areas with established operators such as Virgin Media, O2 and CityFibre. Despite Openreach's line losses to rivals, Shurmer warns that existing measures may hinder their fibre broadband targets. Altogether, however, contend that competition is still developing, with concerns over revised area definitions. The regulator faces the challenge of balancing interests in a transitional market, with final proposals for TAR 2026 expected soon. (Source: ISPreview)

Bouygues has lowered the price of its recently launched entry- level 1Gbps triple- play offer, Bbox Rentree. Just two weeks after its introduction, the monthly rate during the first year has been reduced from €28.99 to €26.99. The standard price thereafter has also been cut, dropping from €35.99 to €33.99/month. The minimum commitment period remains 12 months. This price package is more generous than Bouygues's previous entry- level option, the 'Bbox Fit' dual- play package, which did not include TV content. While matching the connectivity features and VoIP allowance of this earlier offer, 'Bbox Rentree' also includes a 4K- enabled set- top box, providing access to over 180 channels and 100 hours of TV recording. (Source: Telecompaper)
Sky Switzerland has launched new Sky Fiber and Sky Mobile connectivity services using the

nationwide network infrastructure of Salt. SkyTber offers symmetrical broadband speeds of up to 2.5Gbps from CHF35/month in combination with a Sky Show or Sky Sport subscription. New and existing customers can get Sky Fiber for CHF55/month without a streaming TV subscription The Sky Mobile service offers unlimited 5G data, texts and calls with two price plans for Switzerland and Europe/North America, costing CHF17.95/month and CHF29.95/month respectively with a Sky Show or Sky Sport Pass subscription. Without a Sky streaming subscription, the two mobile plans cost CHF22.95 and €34.95/month respectively. (Source: Telecompaper)

T- Mobile has launched 'SuperMobile' business plans, designed to offer enhanced services. Companies like Delta Air Lines and Axis Energy Services are already exploring these plans. SuperMobile integrates network slicing, built- in security, and T- Satellite into a single offering, aiming to provide enhanced performance, security, and improved coverage for businesses. The plan features a nationwide network slice tailored for business. This ensures lower latency, faster 5G speeds, and dynamic resource optimization to meet business needs in real- time. Built- in security on the TMUS Mobile Network includes enhanced encryption, advanced device authentication, and privacy protections, along with Threat Protect for additional smartphone security. The plan also offers access to T- Mobile's satellite- to- mobile network, connecting directly to capable smartphones and supporting over 100 device types with coverage from more than 650 satellites. (Source: Company reports)

Deutsche Telekom installed more than 240k new fibre- optic connections in July, up around \(12\%\) from the number of installations completed in July 2024. A total of \(37.1\mathrm{m}\) homes and businesses across Germany now have access to fibre broadband speeds of up to \(100\mathrm{Mbps}\) with more than \(31.6\mathrm{m}\) premises having access to speeds of up to \(250\mathrm{Mbps}\) , and over \(11.3\mathrm{m}\) able to access speeds of up to 2 Gbps. Deutsche Telekom also passed the milestone of over one million fibre- optic connections in the state of Baden- Wuerttemberg, reaching around \(1.1\mathrm{m}\) homes in July. It has deployed, or is working to deploy, fibre- optic cables in \(80\%\) of the 1,101 municipalities across the state. (Source: Telecompaper)

The German government has started a public consultation on developing a national data centre strategy. Interested parties can submit comments until 21st September, and the input will contribute to a strategy paper outlining the policy, which should be published by year- end. The ministry said this may lead to action in areas such as dedicated planning procedures for data centres, work on securing power supplies and quicker connections to the electricity grid, support for developing new and existing locations for data centres and further work on innovative technology for the infrastructure. According to a recent report from CBRE, Frankfurt is already the second- largest data centre colocation market in Europe, after London. The Frankfurt region surpassed 1GW of built or planned capacity in Q2 2025, the property developer estimates. The more than \(20\%\) compound growth there in the past decade has been driven by the presence of the De- Cix internet exchange in Frankfurt, providing links to networks around the world. (Source: Telecompaper)

Telesat has announced the appointment of Donald Tremblay as its new chief financial officer (CFO) from 20th October to replace Andrew Browne, who declared in March that he would be retiring, after serving as CFO since 2019. Tremblay was most recently CFO at Champion Iron and has over 35 years of financial expertise and leadership experience overall, including in equity and debt capital markets transactions, mergers and acquisitions, compliance, and risk management. Among other things, he has been CFO at Transalta and at Brookfield Renewable. (Source: Telecompaper)

J.P. Morgan uses the following rating system: Overweight (over the duration of the price target indicated in this report, we expect this stock will outperform the average total return of the stocks in the Research Analyst's, or the Research Analyst's team's, coverage universe); Neutral (over the duration of the price target indicated in this report, we expect this stock will perform in line with the average total return of the stocks in the Research Analyst's, or the Research Analyst's team's, coverage universe); and Underweight (over the duration of the price target indicated in this report, we expect this stock will underperform the average total return of the stocks in the Research Analyst's, or the Research Analyst's team's, coverage universe. NR is Not Rated. In this case, J.P. Morgan has removed the rating and, if applicable, the price target, for this stock because of either a lack of a sufficient fundamental basis or for legal, regulatory or policy reasons. The previous rating and, if applicable, the price target, no longer should be relied upon. An NR designation is not a recommendation or a rating. In Americas equity research, some stocks under coverage have a rating but no price target; in these cases, we expect the stock will outperform/perform in line/underperform the average total return of the stocks in the Research Analyst's, or the Research Analyst's team's, coverage universe over the next six to 12 months. In our Asia (ex- Australia and ex- India) and U.K. small- and mid- cap Equity Research, each stock's expected total return is compared to the expected total return of a benchmark country market index, not to those Research Analysts' coverage universe. If it does not appear in the Important Disclosures section of this report, the certifying Research Analyst's coverage universe can be found on J.P. Morgan's Research website, https://www.jpmorganmarkets.com.
